Records was made possible by a generous grant from the Henry Luce Foundation.New-York Historical SocietyNew-York Historical Society170 Central Park WestNew York, NY 10024(212) 873-3400This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2021-03-12T20:47:21Describing Archives: A Content Standard The materials in the collection are in English.
New-York Historical Society
Time Inc. Sports Illustrated Publishing and Business Records
Time, inc.
MS 3009-RG 35
36.6 Linear feet in 36 record cartons, 1 document case, and 1 flat box
1950s-1993 Sports Illustrated (SI) launched on August 16, 1954 as a weekly magazine with managing editor Sidney James and publisher Harry Phillips. The Sports Illustrated (SI) Publishing and Business Records contain files from the deparments in charge of permissions, advertising sales, advertising promotion, merchandising, and market research. This record group contains extensive records on the early years of SI including early memoranda from managing editor James in the merchandising files.
It also contains extensive records documenting the promotion of SI, particularly to potential advertisers, through awards ceremonies, collaborative events with communities, and scripted presentations to a variety of advertisers during SI's first year of publication. The advertising promotion files also include hundreds of taped interviews with sports figures which SI sent out as part of a tape service to radio and television stations. These materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact manuscripts@nyhistory.org prior to your research visit to coordinate access. Keep in mind that it will take up to five (5) business days for collections to arrive, and you should plan your research accordingly.
Conditions Governing Access
Open to qualified researchers with the exception of restricted materials. Restricted materials include contracts and are located in box R65. Boxes that are solely audiovisual material are also restricted as unreformatted audiovisual material in the collection is not accessible. Please contact the curator at manuscripts@nyhistory.org regarding access.
Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact manuscripts@nyhistory.org prior to your research visit to coordinate access. Keep in mind that it will take between two (2) and five (5) business days for collections to arrive, and you should plan your research accordingly.
Historical Note
Sports Illustrated (SI) launched on August 16, 1954 as a weekly magazine with managing editor Sidney James and publisher Harry Phillips.
According to an unsigned capsule history in the General Files, Time Inc. cofounder and president Henry R. Luce asked executive vice president Howard Black to come up with new publishing venture ideas. Black's May 21, 1953 letter to Luce contained a paragraph reading: "A Sports Weekly -- everything in sports -- hunting, fishing, boating. this would be a picture magazine -- 10 cents a copy." By June 1953, Time Inc. set up a department to develop this magazine.
The "Editorial Notes" in the General Files state that SI was the first Time Inc. magazine to include bylines. It started with well-known sports writers. Later it incorporated articles from famous authors such as "[William] Faulkner and Catherine Drinker Bowen on the Derby," and "Robert Frost on the All-Star Game." Notable sports writers also began their careers as early SI staff writers including Robert Creamer and "Tex" Maule.
For the majority of Time Inc.'s existence, the company maintained a strict separation of editorial from the publishing and business side of each magazine, colloquially called the separation of "church" (editorial) and "state" (publishing). Publishing and Business Management includes the publisher, general manager, business manager, advertising sales, marketing services, letters, circulation, and public relations. The editorial side reported up to the editor-in-chief and the publishing/business side reported up to the corporate business executive which was the president prior to 1960 and the chief executive officer after. Luce structured Time Inc. this way so that the business side could not (in theory) influence the editorial content of the publications. For example, the advertising sales people could not interfere with a magazine's decision to run an article on the dangers of cigarette smoking, even though it might mean losing millions of dollars in tobacco ads.
Citations:
Hooper, Bill. Email to Holly Deakyne, 10 June 2016.
Provenance
Gift of Time Inc. in 2015.
Preferred Citation
This record group should be cited as Time Inc. Sports Illustrated Publishing and Business Records, MS 3009-RG 35, New-York Historical Society.
Processing Information
The collection was processed by Holly Deakyne in 2020 and 2021. The original folders were retained when possible, although some documents were transferred to archival containers in instances of overcrowding, if the original folder was in poor condition or undersized, or if no original folder was present. Series were defined by Deakyne. Deakyne created the inventory and other descriptive notes to produce this finding aid.
Related Materials
This finding aid relates to just one record group of the Time Inc. Records. For information about the other record groups and for overall information about the archives, please see the Guide to the Time Inc. Records (MS 3009). The Henry Luce Papers (MS 3014) were acquired with the Time Inc. Records. The collection of books acquired with the records are cataloged as the Time Inc. Reference Library.
Information about the history of Sports Illustrated and additional records from the publishing and business offices can be found in the Time Inc. Subject Files (MS 3009-RG 1) and the Time Inc. Annex Files (MS 3009-RG 39). Records from the editorial offices are in the Time Inc. Sports Illustrated Editorial Records (MS 3009-RG 34).
Scope and Contents
The Sports Illustrated (SI) Publishing and Business Records document the activities of the offices and staff from the publishing and business side of the magazine, not the editorial side. This includes the departments in charge of permissions, advertising sales, advertising promotion, merchandising, and market research. This record group contains extensive records on the early years of SI.
Of note are the photographs and other records about the SI launch party in Keith Morris's files; scripts of presentations to advertisers during SI's first year; a folder on promotion of the first cover and photographs of early store displays and store windows promoting SI in the Merchandising Working File; photographs and audiovisual of early promotional events organized by SI; the extensive run of audio interviews of sports figures conducted by Morris; records regarding Time Inc.'s trial run publishing Women's Sports & Fitness; and records throughout regarding the promotion and announcement of the of the events announcing Sportsman and Sportswoman of the Year. Also in the Merchanding Working File are early memoranda from founding managing editor Sidney James.
Conditions Governing Use
Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.
Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions
Arrangement
Organized into six series:
Series I. General Files
Series II. Department of Permissions and Editorial Courtesies: Nancy Kirkland Files
Series III. Advertising Sales: Director of Market Planning Robert Schreiber Files
Series IV. Advertising Promotion Department Records
Series V. Merchandising Working File
Series VI. Market Research Studies

Series I. General Files0.25 Linear feetin 3 folders1954-1993
Scope and Contents
The material in the General Files was found in a stack of Sports Illustrated (SI) material to be filed. It looks like records that were collected to document the history of the magazine although it is not clear who collected them for this purpose.
Divisional Administration contains early descriptions of SI, business plans from the assistant publisher Dick Neale, early memoranda on staffing and staff lists from the business manager Ray Ammarell, and a publisher's letter on rehearsal issues. Sports Illustrated History starts with an undated list of answers from "Tex," possibly staff writer Tex Maule, answering questions posed by "Mr. Vaughn." While the list of questions is not present, the answers start by defining the role of the sports writer and continue by stating the purpose of sports writing. This folder also includes a 1960 memorandum from managing editor Sidney James to Henry Luce titled "Reprospectus Memo," an analysis by assistant managing editor John "Jack" Tibby on SI in its tenth year, and notes for speeches and other public remarks by James.
Arrangement
This series is in alphabetical order with the arrangement imposed by the archivist.Divisional Administration: History of Sports Illustrated1954-199341121-2Sports Illustrated History1954-196041123Series II. Department of Permissions and Editorial Courtesies: Nancy Kirkland Files01. Linear feetin 2 folders1956-1966
Scope and Contents
The folders on Policy and Rights History was found in a stack of Sports Illustrated (SI) material to be filed. The contents identify the creator as Nancy Kirkland of the Publisher's Office.
The records are primarily internal memoranda outlining the operations of the department; defining reproduction and promotion rights; discussing conflicts of interest; handling the requests for reprints; discussing the sale of SI photographs to television networks; setting rates of payment for photographs; and drafting form letters to photographers.
The main correspondent is publisher Garry Valk although most of the memoranda are from Kirkland to him with a smaller amount from him to her.
Arrangement
The series remains in original order as it initially was a single folder. The folder was split into two due to overcrowding.Policy and Rights History1956-196641124-5Series III. Advertising Sales: Director of Market Planning Robert Schreiber Files0.5 Linear feetin 10 folders1964-1977
Biographical Note
Robert Schreiber was appointed Director of Market Planning for Sports Illustrated (SI) in September 1970. Prior he was in Corporate Marketing and Economic Research. He held the SI role through 1981 before moving into the Magazine Group research department. The department head lists no longer list him after 1985.
Citation:
Time Inc. Reference Files, MS 3009-RG 3, New-York Historical Society
Scope and Contents
Robert Schreiber's files range from his roles in Corporate Research and at Sports Illustrated, but were filed together. The materials are analysis memoranda from Schreiber and reports and studies from outside firms.
Arrangement
This series is in alphabetical order with arrangement imposed by the archivist.Daily Newspaper: Otto Fuerbringer197041126Daily Newspaper: Schreiber & Whinston Analysis197041127Life: Motivation Analysis, Inc.: Reactions to Life's Food and Movie Magazine197041128Life: Report: Evaluation of Publishing Potential of Monthly Supplements to Life Magazine197041129Life: Study: A Study of the Decay of the Effects Produced by 12 Ads in Life Magazine1968411210Magazine Advertising1977411211Sports Illustrated: Lieberman Research Inc.1972 February411212Sports Illustrated: Motivational Analysis, Inc.1964, 1974411213Sports Illustrated: Louis Harris Associates: Research into a new sports magazine1972-1973411214Sports Illustrated: RMH Research Inc.: Subscriber Study1977411215Series IV. Advertising Promotion Department Records28.1 Linear feetin 29 record cartons, 1 document case, and 1 flat box1950s-1987
Women's Sports & Fitness Historical Note
Billie Jean King and Larry King founded womenSports magazine in 1974 as a response to poor coverage on women athletes in the premier sports magazines at the time, namely SI. They sold the majority of ownership to Charter Publishing in 1976. In 1979 womenSports rebranded as Women's Sports & Fitness (WSF). Around 1986, WSF signed an agreement for a trial run with Time Inc. so Time Inc. could explore acquiring it. Time Inc. ultimately did not acquire WSF.
Citation:
Cretaz, Britni de la. An Audience of Athletes: The Rise and Fall of Feminist Sports, Longreads, May 2019, https://longreads.com/2019/05/22/an-audience-of-athletes-the-rise-and-fall-of-feminist-sports/
Scope and Contents
The Advertising Promotion Department Records document how Sports Illustrated (SI) was publicized, particularly to potential advertisers, through awards ceremonies, collaborative events with communities, and the dissemination of sports news to radio and television stations through a tape service and press releases; and scripts of presentations to a variety of advertisers during SI's first year of publication. The publicity director and special events director were in charge of organizing the annual announcement for Sportsman or Sportswoman of the Year, and their files include extensive records on this award. This record group also contains all files on Time Inc.'s test run publishing Women's Sports & Fitness.Subseries VI.A. Special Events and Publicity Director Keith Morris Files20.6 Linear feetin 20 record cartons, 1 document case, and 1 flat box1957-1980
Biographical Note
The staff newsletter FYI states in his 1987 death notice that Keith Morris was the Sports Illustrated (SI) director of publicity and special event for 32 years. The letter from the publisher confirms Morris was part of the founding staff of SI and states he was one of the best known staff members. From 1980 until his retirement in 1986, the Department Heads Lists have him only as the special events director. Prior to SI, he worked in the circulation promotion department for Time Inc. getting Time and Life placed on newsstands and in supermarkets.
Morris's early files contain some materials addressed to and from Terry Rice. In 1959 FYI describes Terry (Teressa) Rice as the "beautiful publicity woman," but her title isn't recorded until 1970 when she is the SI director of press information.
Citations:
Barr, Donald J. "From the Publisher." Sports Illustrated Vault, 13 Apr. 1987, https://vault.si.com/vault/1987/04/13/from-the-publisher.
Time Inc. Reference Files, MS 3009-RG 3, New-York Historical Society.
Scope and Contents
Keith Morris's files document his work organizing and publicizing events and promotional activities for Sports Illustrated (SI). His files also include extensive records regarding the SI tape service which mailed ending interviews of sports figures to radio and television stations.
Unreformatted audiovisual material in the collection is not accessible.
Arrangement
Organized into five subsubseries based on the original groupings of records:
Subsubseries VI.A.1. General Files
Subsubseries VI.A.2. Awards Files
Subsubseries VI.A.3. Promotional Events Photographs
Subsubseries VI.A.4. Recordings of Sports Figures Interviews
Subsubseries VI.A.5. Promotional Audiovisual Files
Because the file groupings seemed intentional, folders were kept in their original groups/series. There is some overlapping of subject matter such as awards events in the General Files.Subsubseries VI.A.1. General Files7.25 Linear feetin 8 record cartons1957-1980
Scope and Contents
General Files includes Keith Morris's correspondence and offices files containing memoranda and correspondence arranging collaboration events between professional sports teams or figures and product or company promotions; memoranda and correspondence arranging events honoring professional athletes; correspondence with sports teams and product companies regarding product endorsements; photographs of events; and correspondence to media organizations offering copies of celebrity athlete interviews conducted by SI.
Issue publicity includes a schedule for publicity events listing people and organizations, but not the type of event (meeting, phone call, appearance); and telegrams to radio stations, sportscasters, and others informing them of articles of interest in the current SI issue.
Radio and Television Correspondence includes offers for a free weekly mailing of the SI radio tape service to media stations and related correspondence. The tapes contained interviews with sports personalities and editorial commentary.
Arrangement
Organized by correspondence then by chronologically grouped files by year based on the original order. The 1960 Files, 1961 Files, 1962 Files, and 1962 Large Special Projects were existing folder divisions. Other general files were grouped by year, but without the explicit folder divisions. Awards Files1.75 Linear feetin 3 record cartons1957-1981
Scope and Contents
Awards Files document the awards events planned or sponsored by Sports Illustrated. The majority of awards in the files were given by SI, specifically the Sportsman or Sportswoman of the Year and the Silver Anniversary All-American Award presented to collegiate football players 25 years after graduation who have since made outstanding social or professional contributions.

Scope and Contents
Promotional Events Photographs contains primarily photographic material of events planned or sponsored by Sports Illustrated (SI). There is a small amount of papers although many folders contain only photographs or negatives. Of note are the records about the SI launch party.

Recordings of Sports Figures Interviews [RESTRICTED]3.25 Linear feetin 4 record cartons containing 142 items and 2 folders1960s-1986
Scope and Contents
This series contains recordings of several hundred interviews conducted by Keith Morris of sports figures, possibly as part of the Sports Illustrated tape service, to be sent out to media stations. Some interviews are of athletes named Sportsman or Sportswoman of the Year, winners of top honors in their sport, and Olympic competitors. Besides current and former athletes, subjects include coaches, managers, and sportscasters. The majority of interviews date from 1980 to 1986. Each tape could contain up to five different interviews.
Unreformatted audiovisual material in the collection is not accessible.
Arrangement
Organized by interviews definitely conducted by Morris then by interviews probably conducted by Morris. Items in each category are organized chronologically.Interviews1960s, 1983-198541241-99
Scope and Contents
Examples of subjects of interviews in this box include Brooks Robinson of the Baltimore Orioles, Tony Conigliaro of the Boston Red Sox, Ray Fontenot of the New York Yankees, Bill Buckner of the Chicago Cubs, golf pro Hale Irwin, Merlin Olsen of the Los Angeles Rams, and Jim Paxson of the Portland Trail Blazers.Interviews1980-1982, 198541251-26
Scope and Contents
Examples of subjects of interviews in this box include coach Willie Stargell of the Pittsburgh Pirates, radio sportscaster Jon Miller, Tony Galbreath of the New York Giants, competitive diver and coach Micki King, track and field sprinter Wyomia Tyus, boxer Sugar Ray Leonard, and boxer Muhammad Ali.Interviews1977, 1980-1981, 1984-198641261-2
Scope and Contents
Examples of subjects of interviews in this box include several New York Islanders players, Kareem Abdul Jabbar of the Los Angeles Lakers, and manager Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds.Interviews1977, 1980-1981, 1984-198641261-8Probable Morris Interviews1983-198541271-7
Scope and Contents
Examples of subjects of interviews in this box include retired player Emerson Boozer, Ron Greschner of the New York Rangers and his wife model Carol Alt, Lou Piniella of the New York Yankee, and hockey team power skating instructor Laura Stamm.Subsubseries VI.A.5. Promotional Audiovisual Files5.1 Linear feetin 5 record cartons and 1 document case1936?-1980?
Scope and Contents
Records include primarily audiovisual recordings of sporting events or contests and sports instructional films with some accompanying papers. The bulk of the records date from 1954 to 1967. Papers include form letters describing the films and response cards for the recipient to return regarding use of the film. The 1967 Sportsman of the Year contains a full collection of response cards. The files in box 4128 contain materials addressed to and from Terry Rice. Some of the audiovisual is part of the Sports Illustrated tape service based on the papers.
Unreformatted audiovisual material in the collection is not accessible.

2 film reels ; 16mm.Subseries VI.A. Publicity Director Jane Gilchrist Files5.5 Linear feetin 6 record cartons and 1 flat box1950s-1989
Biographical Note
Jane Gilchrist joined Time Inc. as an Sports Illustrated (SI) production assistant in 1955. She is first listed in the Department Heads Lists in 1976 as the Press Information Director. From 1979 to 1987, she holds the title of Publicity Director, taking over part of Keith Morris's position. A September 1972 article from the staff newsletter FYI announced her promotion to promotion manager of Time-Life Video after serving five years at the SI direct mail manager although her files indicate she returned to SI soon after.
Citations:
"On the Move," FYI, September 18, 1972.
Time Inc. Reference Files, MS 3009-RG 3, New-York Historical Society.
Scope and Contents
Jane Gilchrist's files document her work organizing or publicizing Sports Illustrated (SI) events. Specifically, Gilchrist's files document: her planning and publicizing of events related to SI's 20th and 25th anniversary, including researching the history of SI for background material; work done by SI to produced and distributed the official souvenir program for the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics; SI's 1986 poll on American's attitudes towards sports and athletes; publicity around announcements of the Sportsman and Sportswoman of the Year; publicity regarding the swimsuit covers; and Time Inc.'s trial run working on the magazine Women's Sports & Fitness (WSF). The majority of records are correspondence, magazine issues, press releases, press conference notes and invites, press kits, and photographic material of events.
Items of interest include a videotape of an interview with editor Julie Campbell on the evolution of the swimsuit cover for a news segment on swimwear and a letter in WSF Media Lists from Billie Jean King containing her comments on the business relationship between SI and WSF.
Unreformatted audiovisual material in the collection is not accessible.
Arrangement
Organized alphabetically with arrangement imposed by the archivist. Scope and Contents
Lee Wilcox's files document her work as the Women's Sports & Fitness (WSF) Promotion Director as part of Time Inc.'s trial run working on the magazine. The majority of the files focus on WSF although there are four folders either focused on other events or that aren't clearly related to WSF.
Records include correspondence, advertiser mailing lists, and press kits. Press Information Office Files2 Linear feetin 2 record cartons1970-1976
Scope and Contents
The Press Information Office Files contain press releases, photograph files, and weekly reports to the advertising sales staff. The press releases promote sports figure interviews in Sports Illustrated (SI) and other articles, announce SI staffing changes, and report on sports news. Photographs sometimes accompany the press releases. The photograph files contain photographic material of people or events similar to that found in the press release files. Weekly reports include tentative information on issue contents and covers.
Files for 1973 and 1974 January to April were not found.
Arrangement
Organized based on the original order which is chronologically with Weekly Friday Reports and Photographs remaining where found between the runs of Press Releases.Press Releases1970 January-December41441-68Press Releases1971 January-December414469-133Weekly Friday Reports1971-197241451-2Press Releases1972 January-December41453-45Photographs: Chicago: Western Open Party1972?414546Photographs: Father-Son Baseball Clinic1972?414547Photographs: Houston Chevy Open1972?414548Photographs: Hudson Boat Trip1972414549Photographs: Toy Fair1972414550Press Releases1974 May-December414551-71Press Releases1975 January-November414572-96Press Releases1976 January-December414597-121Subseries VI.E. Advertising Promotion(?) General Files1 Linear feetin 1 record carton1954-1957
Scope and Contents
The General Files tentatively attributed to Advertising Promotion contain market research and research on various industries along with ad campaign presentations. The majority of materials have no indication of the person or department. The majority of memoranda in the files are from Alvin Buchanan, who signs off as "Promotion" with some materials from Robert Hughes, listed as a merchandising specialist in a 1954 Sports Illustrated (SI) staff list, but promoted to SI advertising promotion director by 1960. The date range of the materials indicate these attempts to attract advertisers happened during SI's first few years of operation. Stetson was the first advertiser in SI according to a speech by Hughes in his bio file.
The General section contain the market research along with fact sheets about (SI), subscriber research, speeches, and other collected material to assist in the promotion of SI. General files also includes a folder of all the empty folders retained that includes names of companies that were possibly targeted as advertisers by SI.
The Presentation section include scripts of presentations tailored to industries or individual companies to demonstrate why they should advertise in SI. The Pepsi-Cola presentation makes the case for SI as a "merchandising tool." The folder Richard Neale Summary includes a list of 1956 advertisers along with a sales pitch to be used by assistant publisher Neale. On the Move is a general presentation.
Arrangement
Organized by General and Presentations with alphabetical arrangements within each section. The arrangement was imposed by the archivist. The materials were initially in one box, had no order, and were loose or in folders that were unlabeled or had labels with no relation to the contents. Several folders were initially empty, and the archivist matched up the empty folders with the correct materials within the box. Ultimately empty folders with titles of companies were retained as they may have been targets of promotional presentations.General: Empty Folderscirca 195541401General: Air Travel: Report of a survey Conducted Among Overseas Air Passengers Departing From N.Y. Merchandising Working File2.5 Linear feetin 3 record cartons and 1 flat box1953-1957
Scope and Contents
The Merchandising Working File documents the efforts of the Merchandising Department to place displays promoting Sports Illustrated (SI) in retail stores and coordinating events promoting SI. Records come from various staff of the Merchandising Department including merchandising manager George Trescher; Eleanor Lambert, owner of Eleanor Lambert Inc. Publicity, contracted for SI's first year; West Coast merchandising representative Marjorie Kessler; and merchandising representatives Ruth Lieder, Mary Mitchell, Eleanor Montville, Alberta Scribner, and Fred Smith. Extensive correspondence from Trescher is throughout the files. Files for assistant publishers Richard "Dick" Neale and Harry Phillips and advertising promotion manager Bill Scherman include memoranda to them reporting on Merchandising's efforts. The Merchandising Working File also contains some of the earliest correspondence from founding managing editor Sidney James.
Records include correspondence to and from retailers, form letters promoting the magazine, memoranda from merchandising represenatives reporting on their activities and retailers' responses, press releases, lists of retailers contacted, and a few photographs of store displays featuring SI. Samples include posters, brochures, press kits and other specialized printed material promoting SI or retailers mentioning SI.
The presentation scripts from Merchandising are very similar in structure to those in Advertising Promotion although trying to place SI displays in retail stores instead of trying to place ads in SI. "The Sporting Look" refers to the weekly fashion feature in SI, and this feature was used to convince retailers to include SI in their merchandising plans. Suggestions to retailers are detailed in the Launching Letter to Retailers.
Arrangement
Organized alphabetically based on the original loose order. Using the original titles, folders from H to Y were present indicating that there might be records A to G not present. Market Research Studies1.5 Linear feetin 2 record cartons1981-1987
Scope and Contents
The Market Research Studies all focus on Sports Illustrated (SI) or the women's sports magazine Time Inc. published for a year as a trial run. A note in the Redesign Study folder transfers the study to "Susan," possibly SI Research Director Susan Alexander. Most or all studies were conducted by Beta Research Corp.
